notes: Use multiple reagents; lighting/timing matter.

uv_light.summary: Blotter paper often fluoresces (optical brighteners); not diagnostic of LSD.

taste.summary: Avoid taste-testing; unreliable and risky (NBOMe risk).

notes: Cocaine often shows minimal/no reaction with common reagents. Use multiple tests; fentanyl strips recommended.
Simon's test distinguishes meth (no reaction) from MDMA (blue). Use multiple reagents.
Similar to MDMA but Simon's shows no reaction (MDA is primary amine, MDMA is secondary).
Speed/amphetamine paste often contains adulterants. Test multiple points.
Distinctive yellow-green with Marquis/Mecke. Often confused with other 2C-x compounds.
Ketamine shows minimal reaction with most reagents. Specialized tests (Morris) available.
Ehrlich for indole group confirmation. Whole mushrooms: test cap/stem separately if possible.
CRITICAL: Use fentanyl test strips. Reagents are unreliable for fentanyl/analogues. Extremely potent—use PPE.

fentanyl_strips.summary: Immunoassay strips are the recommended method. Dissolve tiny sample and follow strip instructions.

notes: CRITICAL: Always use fentanyl test strips. Heroin frequently contaminated with fentanyl/analogues.

fentanyl_strips.summary: Essential due to widespread fentanyl contamination. Test every batch.

notes: Ehrlich confirms indole. DMT usually yellowish crystals; pure is white.
Very potent. Often confused with DMT. Reagent differentiation difficult—lab testing recommended.
Standard reagents ineffective for GHB/GBL. Specialized tests exist but uncommon. Use extreme caution with dosing.
PCP shows limited reagent reactions. Often adulterant in other substances.
Commonly extracted from cough medicine. Reagent tests limited value due to additives.
Rare in powder form. Often substituted with other psychedelics. Lab testing recommended.
Long duration (16-30h). Sometimes mis-sold as LSD. Does NOT react with Ehrlich (not an indole).
EXTREMELY potent and long-lasting (up to 3 days). Very dangerous due to vasoconstriction. Often mis-sold. Does NOT react with Ehrlich.
DANGEROUS: Often mis-sold as LSD. Bitter/numbing taste. Can be fatal. Ehrlich test essential—LSD reacts, NBOMe does NOT.
Part of 2C-x family. Can be difficult to distinguish from other 2C compounds with reagents alone.
Similar reactions to 2C-I. Lab testing recommended to differentiate between 2C-x compounds.
Research chemical; converts to psilocin in body. Similar effects to psilocybin mushrooms.
Cathinone research chemical. Popular replacement for banned stimulants. Reagent reactions vary by batch.
Mephedrone. Banned in many countries but still in circulation. Similar reactions to other cathinones.
MDE or 'Eve'. Similar to MDMA but less common. Often sold as MDMA. Simon's negative (no secondary amine).
DOx compound. Very long duration (14-24h). Often sold on blotter. Not an indole (Ehrlich negative).
DOx compound. Very long duration (18-30h). Extremely potent. Often sold as LSD. Ehrlich negative.
NBOMe series. DANGEROUS - can be fatal. Sold as LSD. Bitter/metallic taste. Ehrlich negative. If blotter tastes bitter, SPIT IT OUT.
NBOMe series. DANGEROUS - potentially fatal. Sold as LSD. Bitter taste. Ehrlich negative. NEVER consume bitter blotter.
bk-MDMA. Cathinone often sold as MDMA. Simon's positive (blue) but different from MDMA reactions on other tests.
Bath salts. Very potent stimulant. Dangerous - compulsive redosing, paranoia, psychosis. Handle with extreme caution.
Flakka. Extremely potent synthetic cathinone. Linked to violent behavior and psychosis. Very dangerous.
Prescription opioid. Pressed pills often contain fentanyl. ALWAYS use fentanyl test strips with any pill.
Classic opioid. Reagents show reactions but fentanyl test strips essential for street samples.
Very long duration (10-20h). Potent 2C compound. Similar reagent reactions to other 2C-x.
Milder 2C compound. Lower potency than 2C-B. Similar reagent pattern to other 2C-x.
Sulfur-containing 2C variant. Long duration. Unique reagent colors due to sulfur group.
Moxy. Tryptamine with stimulating and psychedelic effects. Ehrlich positive confirms indole.
Foxy. Tryptamine with unique effects profile. Ehrlich positive.
Metocin. Psilocin analogue with similar effects. Ehrlich positive indole reaction.
Miprocin. Similar to psilocybin/4-AcO-DMT. Ehrlich confirms indole.
PCP analogue. Potent dissociative. Long duration. Handle with caution.
bk-MDEA. Cathinone sold as MDMA or Methylone. Difficult to distinguish from other cathinones.
Synthetic cathinone. Similar structure to MDPV. Reagent testing helps narrow down but lab test recommended.
bk-MBDB. Cathinone similar to Methylone and Ethylone. Often sold as MDMA or research chemical.
N-Ethylpentedrone. Research chemical cathinone. Similar structure to pentedrone and MDPV.
Alpha-Methyltryptamine. Long duration tryptamine (12-24h). Ehrlich positive. MAO inhibitor properties.
5-methoxy-alpha-methyltryptamine. Potent tryptamine with stimulant properties. Ehrlich positive.
Methoxetamine. Ketamine analogue. Now rare due to ban. Similar dissociative effects but longer duration.
3-methoxyeticyclidine. PCP/PCE analogue. Potent dissociative research chemical. Long duration.
2,5-Dimethoxy-4-chloroamphetamine. DOx compound. Very long duration (12-24h). Sold on blotter. Ehrlich negative.
Mescaline analogue. Similar effects to mescaline but different pharmacology. Research chemical.
Mescaline analogue. Similar structure to mescaline with ethyl groups. Psychedelic phenethylamine.
Mescaline analogue with propyl groups. Psychedelic effects similar to mescaline but distinct pharmacology.

blotter.name: Blotter (paper tabs)
tips: Common size ~6–7mm square; art/designs vary widely
Cut off tiny corner (~1mm) for testing—preserve majority
Use Ehrlich/Hofmann on corner; purple = indole (LSD, tryptamines)
NO purple with Ehrlich = NOT LSD (likely NBOMe or DOx—dangerous)
Test on white ceramic plate to see color change clearly
uv_hacks: 365 nm UV often makes paper glow (optical brighteners)
Fluorescence does NOT confirm LSD—just paper treatment
Some art inks fluoresce; not diagnostic
safety: Always test before consuming
NBOMes can be fatal; bitter/numbing taste is red flag
If no Ehrlich reaction, do not consume

gel_tab.name: Gel Tab/Windowpane
tips: Cut small sliver (~1-2mm) with clean blade
Test with Ehrlich; may take 60-120s for color development
Gel can slow reagent penetration—be patient
Purple reaction confirms indole presence
safety: Wear gloves when handling
Store remaining sample in foil away from light/heat

microdot.name: Microdot
tips: Very small pellets; scrape minute amount with blade edge
Use Ehrlich for indoles (LSD, psilocin)
May need to crush slightly to expose interior
Test on white surface for visibility

capsule.name: Capsule/Powder
tips: Open capsule; mix powder thoroughly before sampling
Take small amount (~1-2mg grain of salt size) from multiple spots
Use Marquis first (broad spectrum), then Mecke, Mandelin
Simon's test differentiates MDMA (blue) from MDA/meth (no color)
Test on white ceramic plate; observe 30-60 seconds
Adulterants may create mixed/unusual colors
safety: Assume fentanyl contamination possible—use test strips
Never trust color/consistency alone
Different batches require separate testing

tablet.name: Tablet/Pressed Pill
tips: Logos, colors, stamps are MEANINGLESS—anyone can press pills
Scrape powder from 2-3 different spots (surface + interior)
Use Marquis/Mecke/Mandelin on each sample
Check for consistency—different colors = mixed substances
Hard-pressed pills may need crushing for better reaction
safety: Pressed pills frequently contain unexpected substances
Fentanyl test strips essential for any pill
Different colored specks may indicate multiple drugs

powder.name: Powder/Fine Crystal
tips: Use tiny amount (1-2mg) on white ceramic surface
Test multiple spots from sample—adulterants may not mix evenly
Note color, texture, smell (without direct sniffing)
White powders: could be anything—test essential
Marquis + Mecke + Mandelin recommended minimum
safety: ALWAYS use fentanyl strips for white powders
Wear nitrile gloves; avoid skin contact
Work in ventilated area
Even tiny amounts of fentanyl can be fatal

crystal.name: Crystal/Shard
tips: Crush small crystal (~2mg) to powder for testing
Larger surface area = better reagent reaction
Test multiple crystals if batch looks inconsistent
Clear vs cloudy crystals don't indicate purity
Use Marquis, Mecke, Mandelin, Simon's as appropriate
safety: Fentanyl contamination possible in any street drug
Gloves essential—meth absorbs through skin

rock.name: Rock/Chunk
tips: Scrape powder from multiple spots—exterior vs interior
Crack: minimal reagent reaction; use Scott test if available
Heroin/tar: Marquis (purple), Mecke (green), fentanyl strips critical
MDMA rock: crush sample for better testing
Brown/black material often heavily cut
safety: Tar heroin almost always contains fentanyl—test every time
Crack adulterants (levamisole) won't show on reagents
PPE essential for tar—sticky and contaminating

liquid.name: Liquid/Solution
tips: Place 1-2 drops on white ceramic plate, allow to evaporate slightly
LSD liquid: Ehrlich on dried residue (purple = LSD)
GHB: reagents ineffective; lab testing only reliable method
Ketamine solution: test dried residue with Mandelin (orange)
Alcohol/water solvents may dilute reagent—wait for evaporation
safety: GHB dosing extremely dangerous—small volume difference = overdose
Never assume liquid concentration
Wear eye protection—liquids can splash

mushroom.name: Mushroom (Dried/Fresh)
tips: Scrape powder from cap and stem separately—test both
Use Ehrlich on powder (purple = psilocybin/psilocin)
Marquis shows tan/brown for psilocybin
Fresh mushrooms harder to test—dry sample works better
Multiple species contain psilocybin; reagent confirms indole only
safety: Reagents don't identify specific mushroom species
Toxic mushrooms exist—don't rely on reagents for wild ID
Ehrlich confirms indole but not edibility

overview.note: Auxiliary observations. Do NOT confirm identity; avoid taste-testing. Use multiple reagents; use lab testing where possible.

cards.name: Reagent Testing Best Practices
do: Use white ceramic plate or spot plate for testing
Test tiny amounts (1-2mg, size of grain of salt)
Use multiple reagents on same sample for confirmation
Observe color change within specified time window (usually 30-120s)
Test in good lighting; natural light or bright white LED best
Work in ventilated area away from children/pets
Keep reagents refrigerated; replace every 6-12 months
dont: Never test large amounts—reagents are corrosive
Don't mix reagents together—test separately
Don't reuse testing surface without cleaning
Don't assume one test is enough—cross-reference multiple
Don't test in direct sunlight—can affect color perception
notes: Reagents degrade over time—brown/dark reagents may give false results
Temperature affects reaction speed—room temp (20-25°C) ideal
Some substances react violently (fizzing/smoking)—normal for certain reactions

cards.name: Sample Collection & Preparation
do: Wear nitrile gloves throughout process
Use clean implements (new razor blade, knife, spatula)
Sample from multiple spots in batch—adulterants distribute unevenly
Crush crystals/rocks to powder for better reagent contact
For pills: scrape surface AND interior
For liquids: allow to evaporate slightly on test plate
Store remaining sample separately from tested portion
dont: Never touch samples with bare hands
Don't cross-contaminate between samples or tests
Don't assume homogeneous mixing in powders/pills
notes: Fentanyl can absorb through skin—gloves essential
Clean workspace between different samples
Label tests if comparing multiple samples

cards.name: Interpreting Test Results
do: Compare results to known reaction charts
Note exact color, time to color change, final color
Consider multiple reagents together—no single test confirms identity
Account for lighting conditions when judging color
Document with photo if possible (flash off, white background)
Unexpected colors may indicate adulterants or unknown substances
dont: Don't trust partial matches—'close enough' isn't safe
Don't ignore no-reaction results—may be important
Don't assume purity based on correct color—only identifies presence
notes: Mixed/muddy colors often indicate multiple substances
No reaction with all reagents may indicate inert cut or unknown substance
Reagents detect presence, NOT concentration or purity

cards.name: Fentanyl Test Strips (Critical)
do: Use for ANY powder, pill, or suspected opioid
Dissolve small sample (~10mg) in water per instructions
Wait full development time (usually 5 minutes)
One line = fentanyl detected; two lines = negative
Test every batch/pill individually—contamination varies
dont: Negatives ≠ 100% safe—analogues may not be detected
Don't skip testing because substance 'shouldn't' have fentanyl
Don't assume entire batch is clean from one test
notes: Fentanyl found in cocaine, meth, MDMA, ketamine, pressed pills
Cross-contamination during production is common
Some analogues (carfentanil, novel fentanyls) may not trigger test
Free fentanyl test strips available in many areas

cards.name: Xylazine Test Strips
do: Use for opioid samples—xylazine increasingly common adulterant
Follow same procedure as fentanyl strips
Test opioids, especially heroin and pressed pills
notes: Xylazine (veterinary sedative) causes severe wounds, doesn't respond to naloxone
Often mixed with fentanyl in street opioids
Test strips available through harm reduction organizations

cards.name: UV/Blacklight (365–395 nm)
do: Use near‑UV flashlight (365nm wavelength best)
Observe fluorescence in dark room for best visibility
Check both sides of blotter paper
dont: Fluorescence ≠ LSD; many papers/inks glow
Don't use as primary identification method
Don't stare at UV source—eye damage risk
notes: Paper brighteners glow blue‑white; not diagnostic of LSD
Some inks fluoresce green/orange—still not definitive
Useful as quick screen but MUST follow with Ehrlich test

cards.name: Taste/Tongue Testing (NEVER DO THIS)
dont: NEVER lick, bite, or touch substances to tongue
NEVER 'gum' or sublingual test unknown substances
NEVER rely on bitter/numbing sensations for ID
notes: NBOMes taste bitter/metallic AND can be fatal
Fentanyl analogues can be absorbed through mucous membranes
Many substances taste similar—completely unreliable
LSD should have no taste—bitter = danger, but no taste ≠ safe

cards.name: Laboratory Testing (Gold Standard)
do: Use for definitive identification and purity analysis
Submit samples to drug checking services where available
Common methods: GC/MS, FTIR, HPLC
Provides exact substance ID and percentage purity
notes: Only lab testing definitively identifies substances and quantifies purity
Reagents are presumptive—they suggest but don't prove
Lab testing may take days to weeks for results

cards.name: Reagent Storage & Shelf Life
do: Store in refrigerator (not freezer)
Keep bottles tightly sealed when not in use
Keep away from light (amber glass bottles ideal)
Label with date opened
Replace every 6-12 months even if unused
dont: Don't leave bottles open—moisture and air degrade reagents
Don't expose to direct sunlight or heat
Don't freeze—can cause bottles to crack
notes: Degraded reagents turn brown/dark and give false results
Marquis turns brown fastest; check before each use
Fresh reagents are clear or light-colored (except Mandelin)
Discard if color changed significantly or past expiration

cards.name: Avoiding Cross-Contamination
do: Use new surface or clean thoroughly between tests
Change gloves between different samples
Use separate implements for each substance
Wash testing surface with isopropyl alcohol + water
Dispose of used materials safely
dont: Never reuse testing surface without cleaning
Don't touch multiple samples with same tool
notes: Trace fentanyl contamination from one sample can transfer
Even invisible residue can affect results

exposure_steps: Fresh air, remove contaminated clothing, flush skin

overview.title: Medical Emergency Response & Hospital Treatment
overview.warning: ⚠️ THIS IS EDUCATIONAL INFORMATION ONLY. In a medical emergency, ALWAYS call emergency services (911 in US) immediately. Time is critical.
overview.good_samaritan: Most US states and many countries have Good Samaritan laws protecting people who call for help during a drug emergency from arrest or prosecution.

emergency_response.name: Immediate Actions (Before Help Arrives)
steps: 1. CALL 911 / Emergency Services immediately - don't wait to see if symptoms improve
2. Stay with the person - never leave them alone
3. Recovery position - if unconscious but breathing, place on their side to prevent choking
4. Check breathing - if not breathing normally, begin CPR if trained
5. Keep warm - cover with blanket, maintain body temperature
6. Stay calm - reassure the person if conscious
7. Collect information - what was taken, how much, when, what route
what_to_tell_ems: Be HONEST about what substance was taken - doctors can't help properly without this info
Any other drugs or alcohol consumed
Bring pill bottles, drug samples, or paraphernalia if safe to do so
do_not: DO NOT induce vomiting unless specifically instructed by medical personnel
DO NOT give food or drink if person is unconscious or having seizures
DO NOT put person in cold shower or bath (risk of drowning, shock)
DO NOT try to 'walk it off'
DO NOT restrain violently - risk of injury, hyperthermia
DO NOT withhold information from medical staff

opioid_overdose.name: Opioid Overdose (Heroin, Fentanyl, Morphine, Oxycodone)
prehospital: Naloxone (Narcan) nasal spray or injection - reverses opioid effects
Multiple doses may be needed for fentanyl
Rescue breathing or CPR if not breathing
hospital: IV naloxone continuous infusion (fentanyl requires longer monitoring)
Oxygen support or mechanical ventilation if needed
notes: Naloxone wears off in 30-90 minutes but drug may last longer - hospital observation critical
Fentanyl and analogues may require repeated naloxone doses
Withdrawal can begin immediately after naloxone - uncomfortable but not life-threatening

stimulant_overdose.name: Stimulant Overdose/Toxicity (Cocaine, Meth, MDMA, Cathinones)
hospital: Benzodiazepines (Valium, Ativan) for agitation, seizures, blood pressure
Active cooling for hyperthermia (ice packs, cooling blankets, cold IV fluids)
Cardiac monitoring and treatment for arrhythmias
Antihypertensives if blood pressure dangerously high
Treatment for rhabdomyolysis (muscle breakdown) with aggressive hydration
Possible intubation and sedation for severe agitation
notes: No specific antidote - treatment is supportive
Hyperthermia (>104°F/40°C) is medical emergency - can cause organ failure
Serotonin syndrome risk with MDMA - requires cooling and sedation
Cardiac complications can occur hours after use

psychedelic_crisis.name: Psychedelic Bad Trip / Acute Anxiety (LSD, Psilocybin, 2C-x, NBOMes, DOx)
prehospital: Reassurance: 'You took a drug, this will end, you're safe'
Do not physically restrain unless absolutely necessary for safety
hospital: Benzodiazepines for severe anxiety/agitation (not routinely needed)
Talk-down technique: calm reassurance, reality orientation
Monitoring vital signs (NBOMes and DOx can cause dangerous symptoms)
Most patients do not need medication - supportive care sufficient
notes: Classic psychedelics (LSD, psilocybin) are not physically dangerous in overdose
NBOMes are dangerous - can cause seizures, hyperthermia, death
DOx compounds last 12-30 hours - prolonged hospital stay may be needed
Antipsychotics generally avoided (can worsen symptoms)

dissociative_toxicity.name: Dissociative Overdose (Ketamine, PCP, DXM, MXE, 3-MeO-PCP)
signs: High blood pressure and heart rate
prehospital: Do not restrain unless necessary - increases injury/hyperthermia risk
hospital: Monitoring and support of vital signs
Observation until fully conscious and oriented
Activated charcoal if recent oral ingestion and patient cooperative
notes: PCP can cause extreme, unpredictable violence - chemical sedation often needed
Most dissociatives wear off with supportive care
Respiratory depression possible at high doses

ghb_overdose.name: GHB/GBL Overdose
prehospital: Be prepared for sudden awakening (can be agitated)
hospital: Treatment typically short (2-4 hours) as drug wears off quickly
notes: Very narrow margin between recreational dose and overdose
Combining with alcohol is extremely dangerous
Patients often wake up suddenly and may try to leave - dangerous if still impaired

serotonin_syndrome.name: Serotonin Syndrome (MDMA, combinations with antidepressants)
notes: Can be life-threatening if untreated
Risk increased when combining MDMA/other drugs with SSRIs, MAOIs
Usually resolves within 24 hours if drug stopped and supportive care given

general_supportive.name: General Hospital Supportive Care (All Overdoses)
common_interventions: Blood tests: electrolytes, kidney/liver function, drug screen
ECG to check for cardiac abnormalities
Activated charcoal if recent oral ingestion (within 1 hour) and patient alert

legal_protections.name: Legal Protections for Seeking Help
good_samaritan_laws: Most US states have 'Good Samaritan' or '911 Immunity' laws
These protect callers from arrest/prosecution for drug possession when calling 911
Protection typically extends to the person overdosing AND the person calling
Minor drug offenses usually covered; may not protect large-scale dealing
Laws vary by state - check local laws, but ALWAYS call anyway in emergency
naloxone_access: Naloxone (Narcan) available without prescription in most states
Often free from harm reduction organizations, health departments
Pharmacies in most states can dispense without prescription
Carry naloxone if you or friends use opioids

after_treatment.name: After Emergency Treatment
recommendations: Consider substance use treatment or counseling
Reduce or stop use - tolerance drops quickly, same dose can overdose again
Never use alone - have someone present who can call for help
Start with small doses if resuming use
Tell your doctor about the incident - they can help prevent future emergencies

link_display_rules.warning_text: Education only. Presumptive tests ≠ lab confirmation.
